reviews.review_title: Action becomes boringly routine, no plot, unfair to Bangladesh
reviews.content:
I didn't have high expectations for this movie, but I figured a Chris Hemsworth action pic would provide a couple hours of diverting of pulp entertainment.
Where did it go wrong for me?
The action scenes were well choreographed with lots of fiery explosions, chases & hand to hand combat etc, but about half way through the film it got to the point where it became cartoonish & mechanical. The swarms of bad guys were inept & couldn't shoot straight to the point where it was hard to believe our hero was in any real danger, whatever the odds. It all became very predicable & mind numbing.
The plot is weak, even for pulp. The story revolves around a kidnapping, the reason for which is never really established. Hemsworths character is a walking "mercenary with a painful past" cliché. The quiet, intimate scenes meant to show his humanity are painfully, awkwardly done, as unbelievable as the overdone action sequences and feel like pro forma filler. Too many unbelievable coincidences. Very senseless & disjointed.
Having said all that, I might have given this film a "5" as an action pic if it wasn't for its arbitrary and misleading setting in Bangladesh. As I watched the film I kept thinking that the portrayal of the of city Dhaka is very harsh. Criminals controlling the army & police, a dirty, filthy city, gangs roaming the streets, including kids with AKs - basically Somalia at its worst. And wondered why would Bangladesh allow a film to be shot in Dhaka when it portrays it in such a negative light?
Well, the answer I soon learned is that this film was written, produced and shot in India by Indians and there are no Bengalis at all in the cast. Now there's no reason the plot couldn't have been set in a city in India, other than of course the Indian producers didn't want one of their own cities to be shown as dirty, dangerous, violent, lawless and corrupt. So they moved the whole thing next door to Bangladesh. Never mind that there's no objective evidence that Dhaka is anything like it's portrayed in the film, or for that matter, any worse than cities in India. Just dump the whole dirty, lawless mess on the people across the border.
I have to wonder if the fact that India now has a Hindu nationalist led government and Bangladesh is 90% Muslim played a factor in all this too.
Thumbs down on Netflix and Chris Hemsworth for their association with this tainted picture.
(BTW, I have no personal connection to either country.)

I am not into action movies, and action movies can get boring if not well directed or just dragged to the limits.Having said that, this movie was brilliant. There was not a dull moment from the start to the finish. The action scenes were exciting and kept me engaged. Of course, Chris as Tyler steals the show with his performance. The movie knows what it's trying to achieve and does it. For that reason, I rated it a 9, but admittedly the movie, if I were a professional critic, is a 6.5 or 7.

reviews.review_title: Proman dao. If you are spending so much money, get it right.
reviews.content:
This is my first ever review and I felt like this needed to happen- not only because as a Bangladeshi native I feel that Bangladesh was misrepresented, but because huge movie production companies have taken it for granted that they misrepresent any country and get away with it. Be it any Latin American country, a country in the African continent and especially Middle Eastern countries.
It seems like they are finally starting to get India right, though Hollywood must think that all other countries around it must be the same. If Netflix went through such lengths to acknowledge a small country like Bangladesh and base the entire movie on it (which is a huge deal for countries which are not always known to the world), then why not get it right? The movie must have spent millions of dollars to produce such a massive action movie only to show a very expensive knock-off version of India. Chris Hemsworth has done an amazing job with his acting, and his action sequences were outstanding. But he could only cover so much of the incompetence of both the story and the setting.
Believe me, the natives who are complaining here are not because we feel that our country does not have any problems. It is because we do have a whole list of them, but none that were shown in this movie. For imagination I give this movie a higher score than I intended to.

Short and sweet...
Great action, Chris, as Tyler Rake, absolutely nails it as the highly skilled mercenary, amazing camera work (don't know how they achieved some of the shots), and talented actors from that part of the world.
Some complain there's a lack of plot and no given reason for the kidnapping...wrong! Voice over explains the warring drug/organized crime cartels. Kidnapping served two purposes... revenge(one can assume) and embarrassment to the father in prison.
Plot... Tyler Rake and his partners are hired to get the boy back, man in charge of boy's protection fails and is tasked in returning boy or losing his own family, man decides to double cross Team Chris and everything goes crazy.
There are touching moments scattered throughout the movie. We see flashbacks that Chris has, Chris and the kidnapped boy make a connection, Chris sacrifices himself to save the boy and the ending is uplifting if you believe that blurry figure that the boy sees is Chris.
Nothing that new or groundbreaking but very enjoyable!
I guess it's a nice movie. There is not much plot to it.....if you are not gonna watch it, then you are not missing something special
The movie was good! You will enjoy probably or not.

reviews.review_title: A good effort of 'extraction' from the boredom during the lockdown!
reviews.content:
In this lockdown, when you are not able to go out, "Extraction" gives you enough reasons to sit for two hours on your comfortable couch. It is a well-hyped and much awaited movie and in the current scenario, when hardly any new movie is being released, this will surely draw a great number of views for sure.When you start watching this movie, do not expect a masterpiece and it will become easier for you to enjoy the journey. Not a very complicated story, good performances and some amazing action sequences will ensure that you are thoroughly engaged.A lot of Hindi and Bengali have been used in the movie. As I am familiar with both the languages, it turned out alright for me but I am not sure about the experiences of those who don't understand either of the languages. But hearing Thor: The god of thunder, saying 'Promaan deyo' is surely going to be a treat for all the Bengalis out there.Extraction - Netflix
Chris Hemsworth carried the entire movie on his shoulders and being the executive producer of the movie he had very little scope to go wrong and to that point, he hardly disappoints you throughout the movie. Between both his falls (his first scene and the last scene), he has given a power packed performance.
The kidnapped kid (Rudraksh Jaiswal) shared many scenes with Chris and he successfully managed to stand tall throughout the movie. But the movie does leave you wishing Randeep Huda's character was a bit better defined. Half of the time you will not be able to decide whether to root for him or not. Moreover, it was a sheer waste to give Pankaj Tripathi such less screen time. It would have been much better to cast him as the Bangladeshi drug lord. He would have made the extraction far more difficult than it seemed at the end.The kidnapped kid (Rudraksh Jaiswal) shared many scenes with Chris and he successfully managed to stand tall throughout the movie. But the movie does leave you wishing Randeep Huda's character was a bit better defined. Half of the time you will not be able to decide whether to root for him or not. Moreover, it was a sheer waste to give Pankaj Tripathi such less screen time. It would have been much better to cast him as the Bangladeshi drug lord. He would have made the extraction far more difficult than it seemed at the end.Sure, the movie does have its flaws but not so much that you start complaining against it. In fact, you should be grateful that in these difficult times it gives you a chance at a good time while you are locked inside your houses.A good effort at extraction, isn't it?
The action sequences are promising and the movie manages to keep its viewers engaged throughout but what the plot lacks is some depth.

reviews.review_title: Boring AF Netflix Action Movie With No Discernable Style or Substance
reviews.content: A somber faced Chris Hemsworth runs around a la Call Of Duty, killing hundreds of people to save a kid from drug dealers. It rips from everything you've already seen, from John Wick, to Man On Fire, to Proof Of Life. The action is ridiculous and the story is non-existent. I gave up after dude gets multiple 9mm rounds fired off right next to his head, doesn't flinch, and suffers no hearing damage, only to continue killing dozens more hapless meandering villains. The action is woefully unrealistic and kinda insulting to actual combat veterans if you think about it, but if you like mind-numbing action, then you'll like this POS.
It is a mediocre story, but an outstanding action and fighting spectacle. Well directed and you get often the feeling to be right in the scene with them. Well done Chris and Sam!

reviews.review_title: To save a Criminal's Son, they killed hundreds of Policemen, Civilians and etc What kind of logic is this?
reviews.content:
I find it really irritating to see that main characters of the movie were killing hundreds of Policemen and Civilians and bombed entire city. I am not sure if it's worth it. On the other hand the boy whom they were trying to save was not innocent either, he shot Hemsworth's friend 3 times, was smoking joint and don't forget he himself was a jailed criminal's son. reviews.review_title: Doom Slayer has entered the facility.
reviews.content:
This review is for the people who can't decide whether to watch the movie or not. So let me get a few points out of the way...1. If you like John Wick or have played Doom before and really like the game, you will love this movie.If you are that kinda person who likes non stop executions, gore, violence and do not really care about the logic and practical scenarios... oh boy you are in for another treat. It's just like any other fast and furious movie out there, does not make sense but does a really great job in giving you the non stop crisp untouchable hero action. Just as I said, if you love Doom, you'll love this.
Because Chris Hemsworth has done it again ladies and gentleman. A banger yet again. I wouldn't say a masterclass, but good.2. If you're that kinda guy who doesn't like being left hanging for dead in the end, JUST WALK AWAYNow, if you're that kinda person who wants to understand the complete plot, who doesn't really like thinking about the movie for weeks, analyzing every aspect of the movie to understand the ending? Like I said. JUST WALK AWAY.But hey, every movie is unique in it's own perspective. You gotta appreciate the efforts put in.3. If you're that person who likes to appreciate the bonding between the people, like to just flow through emotions, viewing the scenario through one's shoes, THIS IS JUST WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR.If you're the person who really binds with the characters on the screen, really like empathizing, go ahead. Extraction does a good job in portraying the different walks of life.Now coming to my review:Why 7/10? Here it goes ..1. As you guessed it, Chris carried the whole movie. The others characters were really bland. It felt artificial and I felt the scripted dialogues even before my brain could decipher it.2. Most of the plot is predictable. And again, it's the same amateur mistakes again.The trailer revealed the entire movie's plot. Very poor decisions made by the team. There is nothing special to the plot, it's just raw. And RAW as in Gordon Ramsey's verses.3. The sound effects was very average. The sounds of the guns firing, the police sirens, the nades, the smokes, the frags, everything seemed out of place. Visuals were fine, the soundtracks were fine, yeah, Just about does it guess.So all in all, it's just a one timer, nothing too special to watch it over and over again unless you're a die hard fan. I would say this movie is alright.

reviews.review_title: If you saw the trailer, you saw the hole movie

Rake's human and responsible character touched me. Ovi and Nik's character was awesome too. I bet, Producers will not be disappointed if they be given a chance.

reviews.review_title: Where does Netflix get the courage to make the law enforcement forces and the proud army of this country smaller ?
reviews.content:
Oh i see...
1. This country is a country of drug lords where the police, elite force (RAB) and even our proud army all work under one drug lord.
2. There is a lack of men in this country, so young children become soldiers of the drug lord with AK-47s in their hands, as happens in Myanmar, Somalia and other countries.
3. There is no air defense or air force in this country, a few Firingi forces flee in civilian helicopters after washing the country's army, police, RAB, but no one intercepts it.
4. Bangladesh is an extremist, corrupt, drug empire state.
I agree with everything, but where does Netflix get the courage to make the law enforcement forces and the proud army of this country smaller?
5. Bangladesh is a country where all the yellow can be seen, the yellow filter is seen in the movie Bangladesh Scenes.What will you think about this country if you watch a movie in Murikan or European without hearing the name Bangladesh once in your life?

Chris Hemsworth plays Tyler Rake. An Australian mercenary with a tragic backstory who accepts a mission to rescue Ovi Mahajan. He is the son of a Mumbai drug kingpin who is in jail.The kidnapping was arranged by a Bengali drug kingpin Amir Asif. He has the police and army in Dhaka in his pocket.

It also has the kind of video game violence that director David Ayer is known for in films such as Fury and End of Watch.It is not the most original of stories but it is a fine enough action film. The setting of India and Bangladesh does give it a different spin.

Try making an extraction movie in the city center with a 6 lane highway! Anyway, lot of action and amazing acting.10/10 for the action and how it was showed. I would love to watch it again with Chris. My God, this guy needs to be a character in Call of Duty!WATCH IT!

Sam Hargrave is the stunt coordinator for the Russo brothers and they seem to have given him his first chance at directing a full length feature. He does a perfectly adequate job with the highlight being the action sequences as one would expect from an experienced stunt coordinator. That's not to say that this is one stunt after another. There are some good stuff in between. The exterior locations are exotic. There are some good Indian actors in the villain roles. The roof top scene with the kids is fun. I would suggest a different way to go with Ovi. I would go younger and make it a girl to heighten the danger. It should be Man on Fire. One thing that does occur to me. Hemsworth is doing his Rambo in this movie and he could do the remake.
Awesome action nd super movie, action like a super fast,

Hargrave saturates everything with the standard present day dark, moody style, with a gloomy, blurred shooting style, setting the overall tone for the film itself. If it hadn't been so heavy and humourless, and a little shorter and less self indulgent, it could have passed as a harmless, run of the mill actioner, something to nod off to late at night, but instead it's one big, overblown event that seems to be stabbing at something deeper. Hemsworth is effective and convincing as an action hero, there's a depressingly authentic recreation of the Indian slums and it livens up at the end, with some pretty decent action, but it all amounts to the same thing.

IN vehicles and a near-obligatory exploding helicopter. Chris Hemsworth really impresses as Tyler Rake as does Randeep Hooda as Saju; the rest of the cast are solid enough too. With its near non-stop violence this certainly won't be for everybody but if you want an action movie and enjoyed films like 'John Wick' and 'The Raid' this is sure to appeal to you.

Extraction - A 1h 56 min action , thriller movie released on April 2020 on the platform of Netflix.
The movie is directed by Sam Hargrave, and stars Chris Hemswort (Tyler Rake), Bryon Lerum(Rake's son), Ryder Lerum(Rake's son ) , Randeep Hooda (Saju), Rudraksh Jaiswal (Omi Mahajan) and others.
This new Netflix original action movie is based on a graphic novel co authored by the Russo brothers.
The movie Extraction sees Tyler Rake (Chris Hemsworth)as a black market mercenary , who is enlisted to rescue the kidnapped son (Rudhraksh Jaiswal)of an imprisoned international crime lord.
The movie has impressive camera work and action sequence.
It's surely a gun fight action movie with some great hand to hand combat scenes.
Although to bring in some criticism , the movie lacked some logic and purpose of reality , with a poor story line.
But if one is looking for entertainment , you shouldn't miss watching it.
The movie somewhere lies in between good and bad.
The movies definitely has some of the best pure action choreogtaphy and cinematography .
Extraction seems fortunately timed for its streaming rollout which could atleast momentarily satisfy people deprived of the big screen.
For the attractive cast and sleek cinematography the movie can be definitely watched for entertainment and action lovers.

reviews.review_title: Shooting spot was not actually Bangladesh, environment, accent is more likely Kolkata, India.
reviews.content: The environment is wrong. Sure Dhaka has slums and dirty places, but most of the city is developed enough with an actual nice road system. If they set the scene somewhere else in Bangladesh, it would've been more convincing. The roads are basically dirt roads in this movie where Dhaka has one of the best road systems in the Country. Dhaka doesn't have that kinda dense jungle anywhere near the city, certainly not near the Buriganga river.The criminal class in Bangladesh is completely different. This isn't Africa, people don't employ child soldiers here. And certainly carry Ak-47 in hand and in the open.The Police uniform and looks are completely misjudged. They are trying to portray the elite force of Bangladesh, Known as Rapid Action Battalion. They are not regular police. They deal with counter-terrorism and similar stuff. It should've been the police that deals with criminal or action in the street. Police vehicles are wrong. Don't get me wrong, the entire movie is brilliantly shot and exceptionally action-packed. But this provides a complete misrepresentation of Bangladesh, as well as the city of Dhaka. People who don't have an idea about Bangladesh will get a false sense for a beautiful country by the misrepresented set of this movie.And finally the accents. the accent of the locals are wrong, they are speaking in an accent that's commonly used in West Bengal, India. Dhaka and People in Bangladesh, in General, have a completely different accent.In one word production team fu*ked a good story.

reviews.review_title: Are you sure this is a Russo movie?

I was completely taken off guard by this movie. It was so immersive and impressing, and I thought Chris Hemsworth and the director Sam Hargrave knocked it out of the park. While there were elements of the story that were slightly derivative, overall I connected a lot with the characters throughout and found the movie not only immersive with the fight sequences but also the storytelling. It's weird because I hated John Wick but loved this movie. It just treated violence differently where it wasn't meant to be feel good, but instead felt more disturbing (as it should). I thought certain dramatic moments could have benefited from less cutting and more of the same immersive feel of the action sequences. Wouldn't have minded it being a little slower to contrast with the absolutely bonkers fight scenes. Look forward to seeing what this director does next.

2. Action: 10/10
3. Plot: 7/10 - linear, predictable, but some minor twists with some tensed moments, but wired up
4. Actors 8/10
5. Story 6/10 - it needed more character development, some more details, some more writing
6. Soundtrack 10/10
7. Culture wise 8/10For me, personally, it was a nice movie revelation for 2020. Took me back to Black Hawk Down, Man On Fire, Slum dog Millionaire, Sicario and you know what, it's all about how It made me feel watching the movie and it felt great!As far as "this is not Dhaka, this is not Bangladesh" comments, let me tell you something about geo-political accuracy, from my perspective, the guy who grew up watching movies about my country simplified to Dracula, Transilvania, poverty and native language portrayed as Russian: GET OVER IT!Thanks.

reviews.review_title: Most time killing movie in this year.
reviews.content: Everything is wrong with this film. There is no any relation to Dhaka city. Accent and spelling of Bengali language was wrong and absurd. The movie was shot in Indian city Ahmedabad, that was totally different from Dhaka. Bangladesh is not like Somalia or Afganistan.

1. Children don't carry rifles on the streets of Dhaka in broad daylight. It's a horrible misrepresentation shown in the movie. If I didn't live in Dhaka myself, I would be mistaken into thinking child terrorism is normal in Dhaka.2. Law enforcers in Dhaka - whether it be DMP, RAB or any of the defense organizations - are NOT incompetent and incapable of stopping two random guys flying in from outside the country. They do their job well, which is why we can go out, visit places, hang out with friends and more without worrying about random shootings (like they show in the movie).3. Dhaka's streets are NOT violent and it's NOT normal for people to fight in public with guns and swords. The movie made it seem like the people are used to things like these happening and somehow it's the norm here.4. An entire movie set to be in Dhaka and not a SINGLE major Bangladeshi character played by someone who SPEAKS the language and dialect that we do in Bangladesh? Are you for real, Netflix? All the major characters spoke Bengali like they do in West Bengal / Kolkata - NOT how we speak in Bangladesh - although they were representing characters in Bangladesh. Why?

reviews.review_title: A great movie for action junkies
reviews.content:
Extraction
Extraction is a 2020 Netflix original movie directed by the Sam Hargrave, a stuntman who has done many successful movies, with his feature directorial debut. It stars Chris Hemsworth as ''Tyler Rake'', Rudhraksh Jaiswal as ''Ovi Mahajan Jr'', Golshifteh Farahani as ''Nik Khan'' and Randeep Hooda as ''Saju Rav''. Extraction takes place in Bangladesh, India in present period, over a couple of days. This is an action-thriller movie.
Ovi is the son of Ovi Mahajan Sr. the biggest drug lord in India and for that reason he lives a very sheltered life, has to come home right after school, gets driven around everywhere by people who work for his father and doesn't have a lot of contact with people. He sneaks out to meet his friends in the beginning of the movie and gets kidnapped by men working for Amir Asif, biggest drug lord in Bangladesh. We then meet Tyler Rake, a black-market mercenary and former Australian Special Air Service Regiment soldier, who has a traumatic past and obviously does these jobs hoping to catch a bullet one day. He gets recruited by a fellow mercenary Nik Khan to rescue and extract Ovi Mahajan. Tyler gets briefed on the plan and gets kidnapped by Amir's men. When they take of his mask, he sees many guys with guns pointing at him and he also sees Ovi there. As they escort Tyler away to get the money a sniper kills one of the men and Tyler takes the other one down. After that we get an amazing and brutal fighting scene which ends with Tyler getting Ovi back. They don't get to the extraction point because an assassin took all the people down. We then get an amazing 11-minute one shot looking chase/fight scene. He is told that he must leave the kid because there isn't going to be any payment from Ovi Sr., but he isn't going to do that. Now this is pretty much all I can say before I enter spoiler territory.
Extraction is an awesome movie that has amazing stunts, chases, fights and cinematography. Now the story may not be that amazing, but the other stuff makes the movie so much better. The CGI in the movie could be a lot better but I let it slide because it is a feature debut film from Sam Hargrave. If you like the John Wick franchise, this movie is right up your ally. This movie gets an 8/10 from me.

reviews.review_title: Excellent stunt but weak story and excessive violence.
reviews.content:
The Action in the movie is overwhelming , with so many gunfights, hand combat, and close quarter shootouts. Both the character of Chris Hemsworth and Randeep Hooda were great in their fights.The accuracy is what is I believe at 60%. The location is picked as Dhaka, especially around the Buriganga river. We have the involvement of Dhaka Police, the military, and another government force known as "Elite", which closely resembles the Rapid Action Battalion (RAB) of Bangladeshi Armed Forces. Most of their clothes were accurate to a good degree, but when I look at the faces of the actors, including the Commander of the "Elite" force, they feel alien to me. Their faces did not feel familiar with the minute characteristics of Bangladeshi people, including facial structure, body structure among others, which made it feel unnatural. I'd say if possible, they should've taken some Bangladeshi actors or background crew to make it look more realistic.The way the characters were talking was also borderline grey as some dialogues felt natural to the way some of the goons speak, especially the kids. But at the same time, the style of talking of the older characters felt more close to something from West Bengal Bengali rather than the Bengali from Dhaka, which we colloquially call, "Dhakaiya Bangla".In conclusion, movie felt good with the action, but there were so many plot holes, as to how Ovi was kidnapped and transported, how Tyler's crew entered the country with such weapons and the logistics. All it felt was something out of a script about getting a "package" out, without any character development.They have done a great job setting up the environment to be as real as possible.
After all being a bengali you will love the Bangali accents in a Hollywood flim.

They have stated in the name itself clearly it's all about "EXTRACTION" so a background plot is missing to some extent. Action and combat scenes are at it's peek, Chris and Randeep have nailed those. Well not a movie you would go in watching again and again but definitely one time satisfactory watch if you love hand combats or dream a life like PUBG or on field military assaults & escapes kind of stuff.

"Extraction" is a high-octane action film that delivers a thrilling ride from start to finish. The movie stars Chris Hemsworth as Tyler Rake, a black market mercenary who is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of a drug lord in Bangladesh.The action sequences in "Extraction" are truly impressive, with breathtaking stunts and fight choreography that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The film also features stunning cinematography that captures the gritty, urban landscape of Bangladesh.Despite being a non-stop thrill ride, "Extraction" also manages to explore deeper themes of redemption and sacrifice. Tyler Rake is a complex character who is haunted by his past and struggles to find meaning in his life. Through his interactions with the kidnapped boy, he begins to see the world in a new light and finds a sense of purpose in his mission.Chris Hemsworth delivers a powerful performance as Tyler Rake, showcasing his range as an actor beyond his familiar role as Thor in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. The supporting cast, including Randeep Hooda and Rudhraksh Jaiswal, also delivers strong performances that help anchor the story.Overall, "Extraction" is an adrenaline-fueled thrill ride that offers both heart-stopping action and emotional depth. It is a testament to the power of cinema to transport us to new worlds and explore the complexities of the human experience.

The movie started really well, and I like Chris as an actor. I thought it was an interesting setting with a decent plot (for this kind of movies).However, the movie fell apart when Chris' actions started to make no sense at all. His moral compass is so out of whack that the whole movie becomes unbelievable, like he acts only to justify action scenes.I don't think I'm nitpicking: to enjoy a movie I need believable characters that act rationally, or at least according to their own logic. So let's see:1) Chris "takes pity" of a kid with an AK that is trying to kill him. He doesn't see him as a threat at all, as the kid is fumbling with the weapon pointed at him. I guess he didn't watch Lord of War and he doesn't know that a bullet from a 14 years old is as effective as the bullet from a 40 years old.2) Then, he's attacked by a gang of drug dealers/criminals, which are teenagers. Because they are teenagers (I assume) again Chris refuses to hurt them even after they are repeatedly trying to kill him. Well Chris, if these criminals that you spared then kill some innocent person as part of their criminal activities, that's on you.3) You might be thinking that Chris is a peaceful mercenary that has a code against killing, like Batman. However, there's a long scene in which he massacres scores of...cops. That's right. Cops. Not corrupted cops, I mean regular cops part of a SWAT team that are trying to apprehend what they know is a dangerous armed criminal. Don't these cops have families? Don't their lives matter? Why is Chris sparing criminals but killing cops just trying to do their job? Oh, to try to hide this double standard the director thought of covering the cops' faces. Cheap.4) Then, he decides to become best buddies with another character, for the sole reason that this other character was trying to rescue the same kid. The problem? This character is a mercenary who just killed Chris's team. So apparently Chris doesn't mind that this guy has just murdered his companions. They don't have any character development (probably on purpose) but still, you'd expect Chris to want revenge for his companions, not to start working together with this guy.5) And the biggest of all: Chris decides to throw his life away for this kid, whom he just met. That's ridiculous. Because Chris has lost a child (because, of course he has), then he becomes so emotionally attached to a random kid (who doesn't look like him) after speaking with him for a few hours? That is absurd. Are children interchangeable now?Wow, Chris, do you know that adoption is a thing?In summary, it ruins the movie when the protagonist does irrational things only to do what the plot needs to make action scenes.

Some spoilers into first two parts..

The ending is like an endless spawn of units on the bridge, which is closed at both ends by friendly groups pushing the bridge for 20 minutes .. what a heck? Plus, the trivial disadvantages for all militants are when they can't aim even at point blank range on the MC. And probably the world is not ready for this yet, but I was waiting - when the moral barrier will be crossed .. at the end the heroine Golshifteh Farahani tried to do it, but .. missed or she didn't try .. - Plot 7/10

The selection of scenes for shooting - excellent locations.

I'm not a seasoned reviewer so I'll keep this short. I thought the movie was pretty good. Action scenes were well done with some excellent, seamless continuous camera work. The plausibility of such a scenario is dependent on the level of corruption in that part of the world: it seems the entire military arm of the country was under the control of Asif (drug dealer no. 2), and the free movement of the mercenaries, through the air and on the ground, may be a little far fetched. But I digress.The main scene that hit home for me was when Rake was critically wounded on the bridge and was thinking about his son. Throughout the whole film Rake is portrayed as someone who has seriously lost his way; alcoholism and drug use, no real direction, and essentially riddled with the guilt of losing his son. Moreover, when he tries to think of his son early on in the film, he is consistently blurred out. The image of his son is only clear when he finally saves Ovi. The theme is mysteriously Christian and redemptive in nature: Rake's soul was undoubtedly in jeopardy before his fateful mission, and perhaps he would have lost his son for all eternity - hence the blurred, lack of clarity. However, as the saying goes, laying down our lives for our brothers and sisters covers a multitude of sins, and when Ovi is finally safe and the mission completed, the blurriness seizes - his actions justified him before God, he received forgiveness, and was finally given the gift of eternal life with his son.

The extraction actually happens after 20 mins from the beginning of the movie. Question is: they can get with a chopper to the middle of nowhere in Australia to pick up Chris Hemsworth, and he can't land the same chopper in the outskirts of Dakka to fly the boy out to the closest safe house?
It could have been over at min 29:34. After that it's just pointless action (I suppose, I stopper watching it then).

The long action shots make you feel like your in a video game come to life. Randeep also shows incredible talent & I can see this as a beginning of a promising career if he keeps it up.

reviews.review_title: If violent action movies are your choice, then you're in for a treat.
reviews.content: You might want to skip this review if you don't like action movies with little plot. But if you're an action movie fan having a knack for violence and gore, you don't want to miss this one.With little to no plot, the movie starts off with a quick introduction of the characters and dives into non-stop action with single-shot car chases, hand-to-hand combats, knives, guns and explosions. Chris Hemsworth plays a likable character, a tough ex-army and a mercenary on the outside and a depressive, suicidal alcoholic waiting to get off of his misery. The kid on the other hand is decent and sympathetic, they gelled together. Another interesting character to look out for is Saju played by Randeep, he is calm and poise in the beginning and would go to extremes to save his family. You feel for him and at times it's difficult to take sides between charactersThe impressive part of the movie is the location and imagery with dusty brown pallet backed with intense action sequences and the cultural diversity. Beautiful colors, ruthless drug mafia, Hindi rap songs and Dhaka families watching Bollywood movies amidst chaos.I think people shouldn't get so bent out of shape regarding the portrayal of the country and people in it. It's just a movie the same negativity arose when Slumdog Millionaire released, people were so upset regarding the portrayal of country and slums but it's just a movie and there's a lot to take from it to enjoy and get entertained.It's fun to watch and relax on a Friday evening, nothing much.

Joe Russo should stick to Marvel films with his brother, because Extraction is one mess of a script. It also doesn't help that his stunt coordinator for his Marvel films directed this movie. Extraction yells mediocrity from beginning to end.Chris Hemsworth is called to rescue the son of a Hindu drug lord in Dhaka. The plot is simple enough, but OOPS, it lacks foresight, character development, and anything resembling logic. It's obvious Russo wrote this script while his mind was on Avengers, because the story is so surface level and dull that nothing feels salvageable. This is because the film moves so quickly to get to Dhaka and the action scenes that there's no time to develop character.Chris Hemsworth plays a mercenary who's ONLY character trait is that he misses his dead son. THAT'S IT! Beyond that, he's just a soulless automaton. The man who kidnaps the boy has no character outside of "I'm the villain, therefore I kidnap kids and kill them" and THAT'S IT. The boy, named Ovi, has no trait other than "My father treats me like a thing" and THAT'S IT. All the main characters have little to no character so I couldn't care about them. The secondary characters have more going for them!The filmmaking and editing are by-the-books bland. Other than the typical shaky cam and odd angled action shots, there's a random LONG take shot that comes outta nowhere and just took me out of the movie. It's so out of place from the rest of the movie-plus it totally doesn't help the action scenes one bit-that I felt the director ONLY did it because he wanted to show off and be like "HEY, I CAN SHOOT A LONG SHOT ACTION TAKE TOO!" I hate using this word-because it's often overused and misused-but it came off as utterly pretentious and unnecessary.Extraction is ONLY getting praise for the action scenes, which I find to be very disconcerting. Like I said, the action scenes aren't anything special. I've heard some people call it the John Wick of mercenary films?? ehhhhh, no. John Wick at least has character and is campy enough to have fun watching. This film is just a mediocre, poorly thought out, sad waste of time and Chris Hemsworth. If you want to watch a really good mercenary type film on Netflix-in the same vein of Extraction-watch Triple Frontier.

reviews.review_title: 1 child's life is worth more than 200 adults
reviews.content: Movies like this really grind my gears.The plot makes zero sense.One bad guy is in prison and have had all his assets frozen = have no money.Another bad guy (who's not in prison and have money, power and the full force of the military and law enforcement in his pocket) kidnaps the first bad guy's (who has no money) son because.... what? To get money from the poor bad guy who's in prison? How did they expect that to work?The poor bad guy threatens his associate (from prison, while being broke) who's not in prison to save his son. Who's still working for the poor bad guy? Why are they working for the poor bad guy? It's not like he can pay anyone.So the associate decides to call in an extraction team to save the son but stiffs them on their payment, taking half the extraction team out instead.Then he comes after the protagonist (Hemsworth) to take the son from him. It's never really clear if the associate is trying to save or kill the kid since he keeps shooting at the car where both Hemsworth and the kid is in. But then all of the sudden, he agrees to help Hemsworth to get the kid out of the city? A very inconsistent flip there.But the thing that really annoys me with movies like this is that they basically kill 200+ service men/women (military and law enforcement) to save ONE kid. Yes, the police chief was in the second bad guys pocket, but that doesn't mean that all his service personnel (the 200+ people that actually died) was. They were probably just following orders, trying to catch an American mad man who's running around killing people all over for no apparent reason.The story deserves a minus score. I gave it 3 because the production value was high and the acting (it wasn't that much acting though) was fair and fine. The story was simply too dumb for me to give it higher than a 3.I'm just so tired of movies where the protagonist runs around and kills innocent people while they expect you to root for them. It's like the old cop movies where they run around in crowded cities, shooting their guns around or having car chases in 200mph through busy business streets, risking hundreds of innocent peoples lives.

Now I cannot forgive myself anymore for letting myself being tricked into watching this horrible horrible movie. The plot appears to be from the brain of a 3-year child, acting of most of the cast (except Chris) is dumb and the whole set is entirely wrong. I believe everyone who helped this stupid movie come to life knew that the whole thing is full of uncountable holes and therefore tried to paint raw violence all over it to numb the mind of the zombie viewers who just love to see blood and nothing else.

Synopsis: "A black-market mercenary who has nothing to lose is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of an imprisoned international crime lord. But in the murky underworld of weapons dealers and drug traffickers, an already deadly mission approaches the impossible."Starts off with the usual action trope: at the end, and then cuts to a few days earlier. I didn't have much hope for the rest of the film. However, it surprised me. The film had jaw dropping action scenes, heartwarming moments, some funny scenes and when the films climax came about you were really in the moment with the main characters.The action scenes are masterfully done with some jaw dropping stunts and great fight scenes. The chase scenes are likewise amazingly done with the camera flitting from the main characters to the chasers, passersby, and others driving the chase forward in a unique way which was amazing to watch.Would have marked it a full 10/10 were it not for a few predictable moments which you saw coming a mile off and saddened me for the fact they'd still use movie plot devices like that knowing that we, the audience, have seen it time and time again and spoils the movie when you predict it yourself. Saying that, it balanced well with other scenes where it totally surprised you and left your mouth hanging open with awe.Overall, an amazing film which doesn't fail to keep you rooted to the edge of your seat. Chris Helmsworth, as usual is at his best. What a rush! Loved it from start to finish. Would definitely recommend

reviews.review_title: This is not a documentary. Why are you all looking for culture in this movie?
reviews.content:
Chris Hemsworth and Randeep Hooda together made this movie great.
Just because it's shot in Bangladesh it don't mean they have to show the culture. It's an action/combat movie. Why do you guys expect to see the culture every time they shoot a movie in different country?! Relax. Don't take it personal.
However, the plot is really simple. But the action was great. Chris and Randeep did their best.

The environment is wrong. Sure Dhaka has slums and dirty places, but most of the city is developed enough with an actual nice road system. If they set the scene somewhere else in Bangladesh, it would've been more convincing. The roads are basically dirt roads in this movie where Dhaka has one of the best road systems in the Country. Dhaka doesn't have that kinda dense jungle anywhere near the city, certainly not near the Buriganga river.The criminal class in Bangladesh is completely different. This isn't Africa, people don't employ child soldiers here. And certainly carry guns in hand and in the open.The Police uniform and looks are completely misjudged. They are trying to portray the elite force of Bangladesh, Known as Rapid Action Battalion. They are not regular police. They deal with counter-terrorism and similar stuff. It should've been the police that deals with criminal or action in the street. Police vehicles are wrong. Don't get me wrong, the entire movie is brilliantly shot and exceptionally action-packed. But this provides a complete misrepresentation of Bangladesh, as well as the city of Dhaka. People who don't have an idea about Bangladesh will get a false sense for a beautiful country by the misrepresented set of this movie.And finally the accents. the accent of the locals are wrong, they are speaking in an accent that's commonly used in West Bengal, India. Dhaka and People in Bangladesh, in General, have a completely different accent.In one word production team fu*ked a good story.

reviews.review_title: Doesnot justify the talent of chris😏
reviews.content:
Extraction was awaited since long. I've been counting on it as the most dramatic action film.I've watched the movie with hell lot of expectations but after watching, I felt that there are multiple grey areas in the story, many of which are incomprehensible.Dialogs are in 3 different languages, English, Hindi & Bangla, hard to watch without subtitles for global audience. What happened to English and dubbed versions? Audience could have lived with these options very well.The cast list is good enough to make it an excellent block buster but seems the story failed to bind the cast with it.The film story seems much baseless and created by some novice writer.The kid of an Indian drug dealer is kidnapped by another drug dealer from Bangladesh but the Indian drug dealer couldn't pay the ransom because his assets are frozen.
Really? That's how drug dealers work? Using legitimate assets and banks? What about the warehouse full of cash lying around as always shown in the movies?
And why would a drug dealer kidnap the BROKEN opponent's kid? Where is the ground for the kidnapping? Or just for fun? How the kid is transported from Mumbai to Dhaka? Using a chartered plane or ship or by road or how?Pankaj Tripathi played an Indian Drug Dealer. Using him for less than 5 mins seems an insult for the actor's caliber as he's an astonishing actor and known for playing a cool headed bad guy in Indian film & television industry. He could have been of much use as either opponent or a strong character in the movie.Which role did Randeep Hooda play? Is he a partner with the kid's father or security or something else. In case he played a security officer's character then the writer must have been drunk while writing his character. The only introduction to the character's abilities are from a photograph dressed as army personnel, no other description.But, Randeep gets full attention in his weak role also, even if he attacks Rake after rescuing the kid from goons.
If his character "Saju" is so brave, intelligent, can travel to Dhaka and fight a bunch of mercenaries then why didn't he thought of rescuing the kid instead of hiring Rake as mercenary when he knew there is no money to pay him. His involvement with the rescue would have been known to the opponent anyway.What about the opponent Bangladeshi drug dealer? What's his contribution to the film other than wearing nice suits, sitting around, speaking nonsense and sipping drinks? And he illegally ties up with a Colonel from Bangladesh Army? Man, it gets worst and worst towards the end.Golshifteh Farahani's character, Nik Khan, handles the team but no tactical experience or decision making in critical situations. The only memorable is her expressionless face.Chris Hemsworth justified his character elegantly and played it very well but details about the character are so vague that I failed to grasp character's motives till the end. The stunts are nicely coordinated and stimulates goosebumps while watching. But, his friend who owes Rake his life, betrays and tries to kill him. Pity on the character for having such a friend.I've seen many Hollywood movies but the lowest grade director from Hollywood may have a better shot of getting nice reviews than Extraction's director.Seems, the film is a waste of talented actors like Chris Hemsworth, Pankaj Tripathi, Randeep Hooda and many others.It could have been a great movie by Chris Hemsworth as a producer.
But, the screenplay writers and the director killed the film with lack of knowledge about South Asian cultures, Geography and people's behaviour.

Action Scenes are on point. Super high octane. Chris is absolutely amazing in each action scene. It feels like butter. Randeep's actions scenes were also very action packed. And car chases are bonkers in spaces that crowded.Movie also takes on things like how easy it is to get corrupted by money like Tyler's friend, who chooses money over relationships. And how kids get pulled into a life of violence like berhad and that little kid, who keeps coming back after you spare him. That kid was funny. And that sewer scene, OMG, I hope that was a fake sewer made just for that scene.Also some things that I think were confusing:
In the beginning on the boat, Saji didn't have to kill the entire team and G. They were both on the same side. Lack of communication right there lol.
And portrayal of Dhaka maybe a bit exaggerated. Never been there but I don't think it's like that, it is the capital city of Bangladesh.P.S: Why you gotta do saju like that in the end xDTLDR:
80% Action
10% Emotion
10% Plot
Go for it

Just watched the Netflix special "Extraction" starring Chris Hemsworth. I am extremely disappointed with the HORRIBLE misrepresentation of Dhaka. Dhaka AND its law enforcers deserve a MUCH better portrayal in front of the world. Reasons below (no spoilers on the storyline). #ExtractionIsNotDhaka1. Children don't carry rifles on the streets of Dhaka in broad daylight. It's a horrible misrepresentation shown in the movie. If I didn't live in Dhaka myself, I would be mistaken into thinking child terrorism is normal in Dhaka.2. Law enforcers in Dhaka - whether it be DMP, RAB or any of the defense organizations - are NOT incompetent and incapable of stopping two random guys flying in from outside the country. They do their job well, which is why we can go out, visit places, hang out with friends and more without worrying about random shootings (like they show in the movie).3. Dhaka's streets are NOT violent and it's NOT normal for people to fight in public with guns and swords. The movie made it seem like the people are used to things like these happening and somehow it's the norm here.4. An entire movie set to be in Dhaka and not a SINGLE major Bangladeshi character played by someone who SPEAKS the language and dialect that we do in Bangladesh? Are you for real, Netflix? All the major characters spoke Bengali like they do in West Bengal / Kolkata - NOT how we speak in Bangladesh - although they were representing characters in Bangladesh. Why? My mother was an actress, a lot of my friends are too. I'm sure many Bangladeshi actors could do those roles better than any of the ones who did, WHILE speaking our language/dialect.Overall, it's a horrible misrepresentation of the country in front of the world by a cast which isn't even 1% Bangladeshi. People abroad don't know a whole lot about Dhaka, but after they watch this movie, they might get the wrong impression that Dhaka lacks law enforcement and is filled with violence.This is not my Dhaka, this is not any Dhaka.PS: This is my opinion on the movie, as someone who was actually born and brought up in Dhaka.

But even after having this flaw, it is still a joy to watch with fantastic direction by Sam Hargrave. Even the acting by the cast is quite good with everyone playing their roles with proper conviction. If you have a strong heart and can watch the utter bloodbath in this movie this is a must-watch for you. My rating for this movie is a very strong 7.5/10.

One of my favourite movies during lockdown was Extraction. This movie is a Netflix original action thriller and it stars the actors; Chris Hemsworth and Rudhraksh Jaiswal. Although Chris Hemsworth in this movie is a very good actor, he is playing his character like Thor.Here is a brief overview of the plot without spoiling too much. A black-market mercenary (who has nothing to lose) is hired to rescue the kidnapped son of an imprisoned international crime lord. But in the murky underworld of weapons, dealers and drug traffickers, an already deadly mission approaches the impossible.This movie was very enjoyable to watch although personally, I think that at some points, the silence lasted for too long. Overall, this movie really hits the nail on the head for me and it deserves an 8/10.

Like a generic Chuck Norris or Mark Wahlberg actioner, it's all spectacle and shallow as a gutter pool. Probably a bazillion people will watch but it really is a tedious waster of money and time. It moves very quickly and lots of people die but, so what? It's boring!

reviews.review_title: Action packed but Character and Plot development lacked.
reviews.content: The plot of the movie is nothing new but it's interesting enough that it will keep you hooked.Performances by the actors, be it big stars like Chris Hemsworth and Randeep Hooda or the Child actor - Rudhraksh Jaiswal did an amazing job. The movie has some well-choreographed action sequences, good background score, and brilliant camera work. Though I think they could've avoided playing Bollywood songs in every other corner of the apartment building action sequence, that too in Bangladesh. It felt like a bad attempt to attract Indian audiences.The movie seemed to lack character development and plot development. It just focused on the action sequences which were brilliant and made you feel like you're watching a good shooting game. The film gets somewhat repetitive towards the end. You can only watch so many people getting shot without turning out to be numb and somewhat exhausted by it. Also, the film opens with a shot from close to the end of the film and It doesn't work however because there is no intrigue behind it. This was one of the few poor choices for an otherwise good action film. I would recommend giving this one a watch especially if you like action movies and games.

Mild SPOILER ALERT!This is your average hollywood action movie. A guy is hired to rescue a hostage and deliver him to safety but faces hardels after hardels which leads to a big blow off and explosions in the end. So, if you have watched action movies before then this ticks all the boxes. The "hero" is a mean killing machine, good in fist fights and knife fights, has the ass kicking persona built in. But unlike your typical movie he doesn't have a cool one line that you can quote, never comes face to face with his antagonist and doesn't rides on into the sunset with a harley davidson.As i said if ticks all the action movie signature moves. It has good action sequences, good cinematography and a simple plot. The focal point of the story is set to be in Dhaka, Bangladesh but due to filming restriction shooting was done Ahmedabad, India. But even with that restriction the locations resembles Keraniganj, Kaliganj, Basila which are three towns across the Dhaka City across the Buriganga River. I think the direction deliberately meant this as in the big blow off scene in the end is set on a bridge on top of a river (hint at Buriganga and Babubazar Bridge). So A for effort. The acting was good too.What is a disappointment (if you are a Bangladeshi) in the movie is the portrayal of the local armed forces. Yes, there are plenty of corrupt Police, RAB (branded Elite in the movie/the guys in black) who work under several political leaders and but involving the Army in the end (i think the direction meant to show the paramilitary force Anser who are always under the Police but got the color schemes wrong and turned them into the Army) is too ridiculous. Two men shooting their way past all of these forces is a bit too much even for action movies as we are not in the 80s anymore.Another down downfall on the movie is the Bangla accent. The language of Bangladesh is correct but the accent is far off. In the beginning it seems everybody speaks Bangla like All British Born Bangladeshis but in the end the accent takes a sharp turn and turns into West Bengal accent. If you are someone from any other country you wouldn't mind, but to us it's a bit cringe.So, taking everything into consideration
a) was this movie enjoyable? - YES
b) would you recommend this? - Probably YES
c) could it have been better? - YesOverall grade: B

The script is so poor, the movie was going to no where. Character development is so bad. We don't see anything that would help us to connect to the main character throughout the movie. The direction is soo bad (Except for the action scenes)
Director used the camera as mere capturing device. Even in an emotional scene, there was no camera work that would be visual storytelling.
Chris Hemsworth acting was so bad in this movie. He just had one or two expressions, and he carried them all along. No effort.
But kudos for the character played by Randeep Hooda. His character was better written than others and he acted so well. Way better than Chris.
There are people who are saying atleast the action is good. Yes, I agree. But movies are not only about action scenes. There's a reason why the universe of Cinema is so gigantic. You have no right to ridicule that grandness just by saying "Atleast the action scenes are good"

Bollywood songs were playing in the households which is not a thing in Bangladesh.
They said Dhaka is surrounded by rivers, which is not totally true. Also there are jungle in the outskirts of the city they said, in reality there are none. Also a kind reminder that this movie highlights the control of a drug lord over the country as he can even manage the armed forces which is a joke. Because drug dealing and drug business is a lot less in bangladesh even less than usa, or other developed countries. Drug is not an issue here. An all powerful drug lord is far from reality. Nearly impossible stunts are at its best which makes me laugh while watching. Also the yellow filter seemed disturbing.

reviews.review_title: Another action movie lost its plot..!!
reviews.content:
Sometimes the smallest detail can trip up your experience of a movie. Forty minutes into Extraction, Tyler (Chris Hemsworth) and Ovi (Rudhraksh Jaiswal) are dodging gunmen in a Dhaka building. They break into an apartment, and the famous intro to Didi Tera Dewar Deewana plays. They alight a floor, 10 seconds pass. Then, from another apartment, we hear snatches of Mehndi Laga Ke Rakhna. What are the chances that two instantly recognisable songs from two of the most famous Hindi films of the '90s are playing at the same time in present-day Dhaka? If this were set in the US, an equivalent scene would be Tyler rushing past one apartment as Rick says "Here's looking at you, kid" and another as Kane says "Rosebud". Not impossible, but unlikely.
Tyler does get Ovi out, but his escape from Dhaka is ruined by Saju's double-cross and the local police closing all exits at the behest of Amir. The film's big setpiece is a very long one-take sequence in which Tyler kills his way from the streets into a building and out again, a terrified Ovi boy tagging behind. Zero-cut extended action is no longer a novelty for moviegoers, but it's still an impressive trick if handled with some wit and variation. Tyler's bloody progress, though impressively choreographed, becomes somewhat monotonous - he moves and executes his kills like a soldier, all precision and no personality.
Its action may not spark much joy but when Extraction settles down for a quiet moment, that's when you're in real trouble. Not content with giving Tyler a formulaic tough guy backstory - his life falls apart after his six-year-old dies of cancer - the film also makes rich, unhappy Ovi, unloved by his own dad, the perfect candidate for a father figure. "He thinks of me...more like a thing than a person," he says, unburdening to a complete stranger who just killed several dozen people and hit the one person he knows with a truck. Later, Ovi tells Tyler, "You drown not by falling into the river but by staying submerged in it", because that's how Hollywood thinks 14-year-olds in India talk.
Extraction is written by Joe Russo, and is produced and based on a story by him and his brother, Anthony, co-directors of four Marvel films. The source material, a graphic novel, is set in Ciudad del Este, Paraguay - the film simply swaps one third world country for another, as American movies tend to do. It's disappointing that the Russos, coming off the success of the last two Avengers films, would choose to put their weight behind yet another attempt to turn white protagonists going on a killing spree in foreign lands into some form of soul-searching. Tyler is treated like a gentle soul in torment, despite his frequent reminders that he is a killer for hire.
The film doesn't have any interest in Dhaka - it could be any dirty, corrupt city where Bangla (and some Hindi) is spoken. The one local character of note - Amir - is translated for Western audiences as the Pablo Escobar of his city. Extraction is by no means a realistic film, but it is set in the real world, which means the Russos can't fall back on comic mythos or easy utopias like Wakanda to explain its blinkered politics. Its white characters, also gathered in a poor country with the express purpose of killing its citizens, probably think of themselves as heroes too.

Just watched the Netflix special "Extraction" starring Chris Hemsworth. I am extremely disappointed with the HORRIBLE misrepresentation of Dhaka. Dhaka AND its law enforcers deserve a MUCH better portrayal in front of the world. Reasons below (no spoilers on the storyline). #ExtractionIsNotDhaka1. Children don't carry rifles on the streets of Dhaka in broad daylight. It's a horrible misrepresentation shown in the movie. If I didn't live in Dhaka myself, I would be mistaken into thinking child terrorism is normal in Dhaka.2. Law enforcers in Dhaka - whether it be DMP, RAB or any of the defense organizations - are NOT incompetent and incapable of stopping two random guys flying in from outside the country. They do their job well, which is why we can go out, visit places, hang out with friends and more without worrying about random shootings (like they show in the movie).3. Dhaka's streets are NOT violent and it's NOT normal for people to fight in public with guns and swords. The movie made it seem like the people are used to things like these happening and somehow it's the norm here.4. An entire movie set to be in Dhaka and not a SINGLE major Bangladeshi character played by someone who SPEAKS the language and dialect that we do in Bangladesh? Are you for real, Netflix? All the major characters spoke Bengali like they do in West Bengal / Kolkata - NOT how we speak in Bangladesh - although they were representing characters in Bangladesh. Why? My mother was an actress, a lot of my friends are too. I'm sure many Bangladeshi actors could do those roles better than any of the ones who did, WHILE speaking our language/dialect.Overall, it's a horrible misrepresentation of the country in front of the world by a cast which isn't even 1% Bangladeshi. People abroad don't know a whole lot about Dhaka, but after they watch this movie, they might get the wrong impression that Dhaka lacks law enforcement and is filled with violence.This is not my Dhaka, this is not any Dhaka

reviews.review_title: Makers of the film should at least have study about Dhaka
reviews.content: The story of this movie is below average. But, some good action I admit that. But, I don't feel it like Dhaka. In this point I would like to add that, the makers of the film should have at least studied about Dhaka. And I never see any people in Dhaka to talk that way as they shown in that movie. The kid of an Indian drug dealer is kidnapped by another drug dealer from Bangladesh but the Indian drug dealer couldn't pay the ransom because his assets are frozen.
Really? That's how drug dealers work? Using legitimate assets and banks? What about the warehouse full of cash lying around as always shown in the movies?
And why would a drug dealer kidnap the BROKEN opponent's kid? Where is the ground for the kidnapping? Or just for fun? How the kid is transported from Mumbai to Dhaka? Using a chartered plane or ship or by road or how?Pankaj Tripathi played an Indian Drug Dealer. Using him for less than 5 mins seems an insult for the actor's caliber as he's an astonishing actor and known for playing a cool headed bad guy in Indian film & television industry. He could have been of much use as either opponent or a strong character in the movie.
(the_rajasthani_Wanderer)
Which role did Randeep Hooda play? Is he a partner with the kid's father or security or something else. In case he played a security officer's character then the writer must have been drunk while writing his character. The only introduction to the character's abilities are from a photograph dressed as army personnel, no other description.But, Randeep gets full attention in his weak role also, even if he attacks Rake after rescuing the kid from goons.
If his character "Saju" is so brave, intelligent, can travel to Dhaka and fight a bunch of mercenaries then why didn't he thought of rescuing the kid instead of hiring Rake as mercenary when he knew there is no money to pay him. His involvement with the rescue would have been known to the opponent anyway.What about the opponent Bangladeshi drug dealer? What's his contribution to the film other than wearing nice suits, sitting around, speaking nonsense and sipping drinks? And he illegally ties up with a Colonel from Bangladesh Army? Man, it gets worst and worst towards the end.Golshifteh Farahani's character, Nik Khan, handles the team but no tactical experience or decision making in critical situations. The only memorable is her expressionless face.Chris Hemsworth justified his character elegantly and played it very well but details about the character are so vague that I failed to grasp character's motives till the end. The stunts are nicely coordinated and stimulates goosebumps while watching. But, his friend who owes Rake his life, betrays and tries to kill him. Pity on the character for having such a friend.I've seen many Hollywood movies but the lowest grade director from Hollywood may have a better shot of getting nice reviews than Extraction's director.Seems, the film is a waste of talented actors like Chris Hemsworth, Pankaj Tripathi, Randeep Hooda and many others.It could have been a great movie by Chris Hemsworth as a producer.
But, the screenplay writers and the director killed the film with lack of knowledge about South Asian cultures, Geography and people's behaviour.
.
by ---The Rajasthani wanderer

reviews.review_title: .....Action packed but completely missed the Environment of Dhaka......
reviews.content: The premise of the movie was supposed to set in Dhaka, a city of 10+ million people in Bangladesh. Unfortunately, they completely missed mark making the set in Dhaka.To start with, the accent of the locals are wrong, they are speaking in an accent that's commonly used in West Bengal, India. Dhaka and People in Bangladesh, in General, have a completely different accent. Throughout the movie, Hindi songs are heard in the background, where everyone is watching tv during midday. People go to work here, Dhaka is the capital, nobody sits on their asses watching TV midday. Bangladesh has its own music industry, although the movie had some issues acquiring copyright for some of the songs to play in the background.The environment is wrong. Sure Dhaka has slums and dirty places, but most of the city is developed enough with an actual nice road system. If they set the scene somewhere else in Bangladesh, it would've been more convincing. The roads are basically dirt roads in this movie where Dhaka has one of the best road systems in the Country. Dhaka doesn't have that kinda dense jungle anywhere near the city, certainly not near the Buriganga river.The criminal class in Bangladesh is completely different. This isn't Africa, people don't employ child soldiers here. And certainly carry AK-47 in hand and in the open.The Police uniform and looks are completely misjudged. They are trying to portray the elite force of Bangladesh, Known as Rapid Action Battalion. They are not regular police. The deal with counter-terrorism and similar stuff. It should've been the police that deals with criminal or action in the street. Police vehicles are wrong.Don't get me wrong, the entire movie is brilliantly shot and exceptionally action-packed. But this provides a complete misrepresentation of Bangladesh, as well as the city of Dhaka. People who don't have an idea about Bangladesh will get a false sense for a beautiful country by the misrepresented set of this movie.Reviewed by oritroahmed

reviews.review_title: Worth watching, not a brainless action movie
reviews.content:
What more can you ask from an action movie other than to be entertained and intrigued from the action. You shouldn't be looking for a deep, fascinating story that makes you think about the wider world, take this movie for what it is.
The well choreographed sequences remind me of the John Wick style of brutally over the top and yet grounded and human, especially the 11 minute one shot and the final scene on the bridge. This movie tries different things, in terms of the suicidal element of our protagonist, and the streamlined plot which contains an interesting half way point with David Harbours character.
I would say this movie suffers from undeveloped characters, including Harbours, Farahinis and the boy with the scar. I didn't understand if Farahini was a love interest or just a close relationship, either way it wasn't expanded upon. The boy with the scar isn't interesting enough to be the person who kills Tyler, and as a viewer it did nothing for me, as Tyler seemed very content with dying, he had accomplished the mission and I'm assuming he comes back to life in the final shot.
We all have hours to kill so you may as well spend 2 of them watching this.

reviews.review_title: Indian Winter Soldier cannot be unseen
reviews.content:
"Need a kidnap victim rescued? There's an Australian for that....name's Russell Crowe.." (Proof of Life, 2000)
"Ok, 1. He's a bit too old mate...and 2. He's New Zealander.."
"Piss off mate..."Extraction.
Produced and directed by the folks who made Captain America: Civil War. Set in Bangladesh featuring an Indian Winter Soldier (gotta admit u can't unsee this)... Non stop action...balls to the wall..pedal to the metal...ok..ok...the action does stop about twice and yeah its does reach its lowest point there but its really kind of expected, I dont think anyone is channeling Daniel Day Lewis here...and speaking of acting, what? They couldn't hire any other convincing Indian actress to play the role of whatshername? Too stiff..she's just there to look good and not act..okay..hehe and oh god that kid's face is annoying...but when the shooting starts man this movie does get fun. Like discount John Wick fun...:) pew pew..pew pew pew.. click click..brrrrrtttttttt...also, there a couple of nitpicky loose ends here. Ahh, never mind. Movie never bothered. So it's fine i guess..Lolwhat are you waiting for? It's on Netflix...ECQ is extended bro...so go watch this, then go watch The Raid and The Raid 2: Berandal if you cant get enough of the violence...;)7/10point deducted for the script writers' missed opportunity to make a get to the choppa reference in there.

reviews.review_title: Great Action but where is Dhaka?
reviews.content:
I am okay with the movie as long as it's just another action movie but the way it portrayed Dhaka is just so wrong.Things I'm OK to forgive:-Wrong accent
-Wrong Insignia in law enforcement uniform
-Wrong portrayal of Dhaka city streets
-Wrong portrayal of Bangladeshi characters ( We are not having a famine)
-Desperate attempts to make Dhaka look like Kabul / Mogadishu
-Completely ignoring Urban & actual Dhaka
-People listening to Hindi songs during noon & sitting duck
( Understandable since the filming took place in Ahmedabad and not actual Dhaka)
-Open food and fish market in the middle of the street; blocking everything
-Desperate attempts to make the streets look like post world war BerlinThings I'm not okay with:-No, kids are not carrying AK47 here for any reasons.
-In the history of Bangladesh we have never had such a drug lord or companion
-Not showing anything from actual Dhaka was the biggest mistake, urban Dhaka is nice, structured & progressive, not anything like what was shown in the movie.
-Employing no adviser from Bangladesh's actual law enforcement agencies or military
-Potentially impacting a bad effect on Bangladesh's tourism industry as many in the west will actually believe this fictional Dhaka.
-No, this ain't 1980's ColumbiaOverall, the movie is somewhat enjoyable. Everything about the movie felt so common with Sicario! Chris is one of my favorite & I must admit he really tried to bring something for the viewers. Better luck next time!

Extraction is an action thriller film directed by debutant director Sam Hargrave and it is based on a novel called Ciudad written by Ande Parks, Joe Russo, Anthony Russo and Fernando Leon Gonzalez. I it is an one hour fifty seven minutes action movie. Main Strength in this movie is its action, the performance of lead actor Chris Hemsworth and supporting actor Randeep Hooda in action department were very good, specially a hand to hand combat scene between Chris and Randeep was worth watching. But the main drawback in this film is its average storyline and weak screenplay it fails to engage the audience for the whole two hours. Technical aspects like VFX is also good but I feel adequate reasearch was not done on Dhaka city because at some scenes of the film we hear old hindi songs in background but Dhaka is a bengali speaking city. Acting performance of Chris Hemsworth, Randeep Hooda and Rudraksh Jaiswal were very good but the performance of Priyanshu Puniyali who plays the main antagonist in this film was not upto the mark. Other actors also acted well in their limited screen presence.

An out and out action, If you are an action movie fan, you will experience a lot of jaw-dropping moments while watching this film.Not jusst another review brings to you the most talked-about Netflix movie that has some mind-blowing action scenes Starring Chris Hemsworth, Randeep Hooda, Pankaj Tripathi and Golshifteh Farahani
Extraction is centered on rescuing Ovi, the son of an Indian Druglord who has been kidnapped by a Bangladeshi Drug lord Amir Asif.
This movie predominantly shows the rivalry between the 2 drug lords.
Pankaj Tripathi has about a 30-second role in the film, where he is seen in a jail instructing Saju, his accomplice to rescue his son Ovi from Dhaka or risk his own son's life.
Now Saju has accepted this precarious task unwillingly to save his family but he knows it won't be easy to get Ovi back from Dhaka, it would be like one Man v/s a Country.
He knows someone who can help accomplish this task on his behalf, Tyler, a black market mercenary. Tyler easily accepts this task and sets out to accomplish this mission backed by his team member, Niz.
The film starts with the climax scene where Tyler is shot, making us wonder whether the movie would live up to the hype and expectation.
The moment Tyler reaches Dhaka, Bang Bang, the action starts, the hand to hand combats, Knife fights, guns, bazookas, bombs, helicopters, sniper. Tyler has all the firepower one man would ever need to fight a country.
There are some emotional moments in the movie. amid Ovi's rescue mission when he tries to look back at his life, he realizes his father treated him like a possession more than his son and in this process ends up knowing Tyler's story where he learns about his 6yr old son who is no more. There is a certain bond that develops between Ovi and Tyler.
The USP of this film is action, action and nothing but action and is so well directed that it is difficult to comprehend this is Sam Hargrave's directorial debut. Sam Hargrave is a stunt coordinator at Marvel Universe and it comes as no surprise that he strapped himself around the car with a camera and said action. The scenes between Tyler and Saju are a treat to watch. A scene where Tyler and Saju fall from the balcony straight on to the road and the way the camera follows them will keep the audience gasping for breath.All in all, this movie is a treat for action junkies, it will surprise you with stunts u would have never seen before, the fights look very real and is very fast paced.
Extraction is based on a book called Cuidad.
The film's working title was initially Dhaka but was changed to Out of the Fire and finally, the makers settled for Extraction.
The shooting took place in Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Thailand.

Alright, it is time for me to reopen my account with this new Action Flick "Extraction"..
Now, why this movie??Because, it's Russo Brothers met Chris Hemsworth met Randeep Hooda met A little bit of Pankaj Tripathi met some of our very own talented Indians met Mumbai met frequent use of Bengali Slangs met unbelievable action met Netflix..It's like a whole dream package for a Indian Nerdy movie buff, on paper..Yes, on paper because some times, the theories on paper fail to reflect entirely in practicals..This film is no doubt, 'The' film with the most intense action sequences ever made in recent history and mark my words, Chris 'Thor' Hemsworth delivers the best ever performance till date mixing it with raw action and dark emotion but some how it feels like the 'Story' could have been 'a bit more', a little bit more..I accept that it's an out and out no brainer action movie but I really feel that the character development could have been better..And Also a quick observation, why Indian Hindi music were buzzing all around the houses of Bangladesh? It calls for a question on authenticity, right?? I myself, an Indian, don't think that Bangladeshis listen to Hindi Music that much..!Nevertheless, it doesn't take away the fact that the Indian Angry man Randeep Hooda fought exceptionally well to take his role at per with Hemsworth..
In parts, it felt like this film is targeted to the Indian audiences, it's like the producers knew what could trigger us to like and watch this film..hat's off Russo Bros and debutant director Sam Hargreaves for this fantantic marketing strategy..
Nothing more to say but I guess this film with it's 'ifs' and 'buts' delivers a popcorn and relaxing treat in these tough times and Kudos to the creators for that..And Special mention must be the precious Bengali spoken by Chris Hemsworth i.e. ''Proman Dao'' ( Show me the proof)..That was shockingly hilarious..!!
